https://prez.dev/description.@value: The types of physical samples that are used to undertake quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) checks at all stages of the sampling, preparation and analytical processes, and/or to retain representative material for future reference. Note that QA and QC are often used collectively as a single term, but are in fact distinct procedures: QA 'refers to defect prevention', i.e. ‘the protocols and procedures that ensure that sampling and assaying is completed to the required quality’, whereas QC 'refers to defect detection', i.e. ‘the use of control samples and statistical analysis to ensure that assay results are reliable’ (Graindorge, 2010, p. 112; https://www.usgs.gov/data-management/manage-quality). This vocabulary thus also encapsulates terminology covering sample representability.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Material with known quantity values added to an analytical sample to test the accuracy and validity of the analytical method. The material can be a reference material or a certified reference material. The known quantity value is often a fraction or concentration. Multiple spikes can be added to a sample (e.g. ‘double spike’ or ‘triple spike’) with precisely known proportions to quantify mass fractionation of mass spectrometers (also known as an internal standard).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
Definition based on:
Hibbert, DB, Korte, E-H and Örnemark, U, 2021, Metrological and quality concepts in analytical chemistry (IUPAC Recommendations 2021): Pure and Applied Chemistry, v. 93, no. 9, p. 997–1048, doi:10.1515/pac-2019-0819.

ThermoFisher, How and why to matrix spike, https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets/LPD/Product-Information/Why-How-Matrix-Spike-ST-MATSPIKE-EN.pdf.
